newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy budget talks went "well" - hardleft leader.
newsitem.headline: Italy budget talks went "well" - hardleft leader.

text.p: Talks about the forthcoming mini-budget with parties backing Italy's government went well, the leader of the hardleft Communist Refoundation said.
Fausto Bertinotti said the package, due to be approved by cabinet on Thursday, would not include cuts to welfare spending.
"The talks went well. I say this because we are not ones to be triumphalist," Bertinotti said following a meeting with coalition party leaders and Prime Minister Romano Prodi.
The mini-budget is expected to include up to 16 trillion lire of deficit cutting measures in a bid to prepare the economy for the launch of the single European currency.

Bertinotti had warned that he would not support any package which included a hike in taxes or cuts to the welfare state. He said coalition leaders had reached a "compromise which will avoid cuts to social spending".
However the Refoundation leader indicated that after the mini-budget there might be an overhaul of the welfare state.
"This opens a chapter which will be decisive - the reform of the welfare state. It is a chapter that is wide open," he said.
Much of the cash from the corrective budget is expected to come from advance taxation on firms' severance payment funds. -- Rome newsroom +396 6782505
